      Based on the 2019 seismic assessments for the Van Norman Complex Chlorination Facilities, 14 recommendations were made to improve chlorine safety. The recommendations for the LAROCS included the performance of a detailed seismic assessment. These recommendations have been evaluated, and implemented or adequately addressed by the LADWP. Based on the performance of the detailed seismic assessment for the LAROCS in 2021, multiple structural deficiencies were identified that would require retrofitting or replacement of this facility. The LADWP has initiated and begun planning on a capital improvement project to replace the LAROCS.

      Based on the 2024 seismic assessment updates for the above five facilities, three sets of recommendations (for LAAFP, LAROCS and VNCD) have been made to further improve chlorine safety during future earthquakes. Note that no additional recommendation was made for the VNCS#1 or VNCS#2 chlorine facilities.

      It is expected that all the above 2024 recommendations will be evaluated, and implemented or adequately addressed by the LADWP by September 2026. The implementation of these recommendations will further enhance the safety of the chlorination stations.

s the City of Los Angeles Fire Department will also be solicited to respond.  

      As part of the emergency response program, the LADWP has developed and implemented an emergency response plan for the purpose of protecting public health and the environment. The following elements are included:

(a) Emergency response plan, maintained at each facility, including the Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) containing:

* Organizational structure (chain-of-command) and responsibilities of various LADWP personnel.
* Procedures for planning and coordination with off-site emergency response organizations.
* Details of the training programs for all employees involved with the chlorination processes, contractor training, and medical surveillance of LADWP personnel who respond to chlorine releases.
* Details of emergency recognition and prevention at the LADWP.
* Procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental releases.
* Documentation of proper first aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat accidental human exposures and the detailed information on emergency health care.
* Procedures and measures for emergency response after an accidental release.

(b)	Procedures for the use of emergency response equipment and for its inspection, testing, and maintenance. 

(c)	Training in relevant procedures for all employees involved with the chlorination processes.

(d)	Procedures to review and update, as appropriate, the emergency response plan to reflect changes and ensure that employees are informed of changes.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

      Based on the 2019 PHAs for the Van Norman Complex Chlorination Facilities (LAAFP, LAROCS, VNCD, VNCS#1, and VNCS#2), 40 recommendations were made to improve chlorine safety. These recommendations have been evaluated, and implemented or adequately addressed by the LADWP. Additionally, three sets of recommendations (for LAAFP, LAROCS and VNCD) to further improve chlorine sa

ompliance Audit Certification Page provides process identification, the dates of the audit, team members, and certification by the audit leader. The Compliance Audit Checklist details the requirements of each RMP element and contain questions that may assist with the auditing process. The audit checklist for each element consists of the following three sections:

* Records Review: A review of the RMP written Prevention Program.
* On-Site Conditions: The audit team will review the program elements based on observation of the plant conditions and safety practices.
* Interviews:  The program elements will be evaluated by interviewing personnel from appropriate functions including operations, maintenance, management, and contractors.

      Compliance Auditor records RMP program deficiencies identified during the audit on the checklist.

Incident Investigation

      The LADWP incident investigation procedures describe incident reporting, investigation, and investigation reporting steps to be followed by plant personnel. The incident investigation is started promptly but no later than 48 hours after the event. The LADWP promptly addresses and resolves all recommendations and implements the recommendations in a timely manner to prevent an incident recurrence. All incident investigation reports are retained in the LADWP's file for at least a period of five years from the date the reports are completed.

Five-year Accident History Summary

      No chlorine release that could have caused safety or health hazard (on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place) occurred at the LAAFP facilities during the last five years. 

Emergency Response Program Summary

      The LADWP is a first responder, its employees respond to chlorine accidental releases. In the event an accidental release that could result in offsite consequences occurs, external resources, such a

ection, test, and maintenance schedules on a daily, weekly, bi-monthly, monthly, biannual, and annual, every 2 to 10 years, and as-needed basis. These procedures allow the operator to rapidly review what maintenance is necessary. 

      The LADWP documents inspection, testing, and maintenance of chlorination/ammoniation equipment and assures the performance is performed in accordance with the recommendations of the manufacturer and industry groups.

Hot Work Permits and Management of Change

      Hot work refers to work involving electric or gas welding, cutting, brazing, or similar flame or spark producing operations. The hot work procedures require the issuance of a hot work permit whenever it is conducted on or near the chlorination process and other areas deemed appropriate as described in these procedures. Fire prevention and protection systems are in place before a hot work permit is issued. The permit indicates the dates the work is authorized for, the location, and specific operational requirements, and it is kept on file in the administrative office. 

      The LADWP Management of Change procedures include steps required to be taken by plant personnel before implementing changes to chlorination equipment, procedures, raw materials, and processing conditions.  Training, process safety information, operating procedures, and maintenance procedures are updated according to the changes made.

Internal Compliance Audits

      The LADWP has been certifying every three years (or earlier) that compliance with Prevention Program requirements for the chlorination stations are met and that procedures and practices developed are adequate and being followed. 

      The compliance audit for the chlorination stations consist of separating the RMP program elements or sections and auditing each element to determine compliance and effectiveness. For each internal audit, the audit team completes a Compliance Audit Certification Page and a Compliance Audit Checklist. The C

tegrity Program

      The LADWP has procedures in place to ensure that a pre-startup safety review is conducted prior to starting a new covered process or prior to making modifications to the chlorination systems that require a Management of Change (MOC) procedure implementation. The required conditions prior to startup include the following:

* Construction and/or equipment are in accordance with design specifications.

* Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate.

* A PHA has been performed for any new facilities and recommendations have been resolved or implemented prior to startup.

* At modified facilities, MOC requirements have been met.

* Training of each operating and maintenance employee involved in the process is complete.

      These procedures ensure that no new and/or new/significantly modified process will startup and no regulated substances will be introduced into such a process before the pre-startup safety review. This constitutes a final check that the process and equipment are ready to go and that the recommendations of the PHA have been implemented or adequately addressed. This will ensure that the design and construction of a new or modified process is safely executed and that the facility is prepared to operate it. 

      Mechanical integrity procedures for the plant ensure that written maintenance procedures are implemented and documented, including training of maintenance personnel.

Maintenance 

      The LADWP operates a Computerized Maintenance Management System (CMMS) software Program, an asset management program that generates a preventive maintenance work order at a designated frequency. Description of the work to be performed is included with the printed work order. The water treatment supervisor is responsible for this task.

      In addition, the written maintenance procedure is provided in the O&M Manuals as follows: Preventive maintenance schedules are provided which summarize insp

ions.
* Bulk Tank Connections.
* Ton Container Connections.
* Initial Startup Procedure.
* Normal Operation.
* Normal Shutdown.
* Temporary Operations.
* Emergency Operations.
* Emergency Shutdown.
* Startup Following Emergency Shutdown.

Training

      The LADWP ensures that each employee operating or maintaining the chlorination processes, and each employee newly assigned to these processes, are trained and tested for competency in the operating procedures listed above. LADWP employee training documentation files include training records for each employee assigned to operate or maintain the chlorination processes. The training ensures that the employee has the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely perform the duties and responsibilities, including chlorine emergency response, as provided in the operating procedures. Employee training includes as a minimum the following elements:

* Safety Information.
* Process Technology and Process Equipment, including safety systems.
* Maintenance Procedures.
* Operating Procedures for the chlorine and aqueous ammonia systems.
* RMP Program contents.
* Emergency Response Plan and Procedures.

      Refresher training is provided at least every three years to each employee operating the chlorination process to ensure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures. In addition, the LADWP ensures that operators are trained in any updated or new procedures prior to startup of a process after major modifications.  

Contractors

      The LADWP Contractor's procedures specify the information required to be provided to the contractors performing work on or near the chlorination process, the training requirements for contractor employees, and mechanism to obtain assurance from contractors that they have informed their employees of the appropriate safety rules. The LADWP provides information and explanations concerning the hazards and processes. 

Pre-Startup Safety Review and Mechanical In

s detailed physical properties of chlorine. This information includes chlorine background information and Safety Data Sheets.

      Equipment safety information was compiled on the chlorination processes. Specifications for the chlorination are collected and provided in one place for easy reference. Details (such as maximum intended inventory; safe upper and lower temperatures; and safe upper and lower pressures for the chlorination facility) are on file at the facility. The LADWP also has procedures in place that are triggered to update process safety information if there is a major change that makes existing information inaccurate.

Process Hazard Analysis

      PHA for the above described five chlorination processes was performed between January and March 2024 for updating/revalidating the previously performed PHAs in 2019. These PHAs will be updated/revalidated again within a five-year period or whenever there will be a major change in the process. A set of recommendations was made to further improve the chlorine safety. These recommendations are being evaluated for implementation. The LADWP staff will document the completion of the recommended actions. 

      Seismic assessment, including walkthroughs for the above five chlorination stations was performed between April and May 2024. A set of recommendations was developed  to further improve the chlorine safety during future earthquakes. All of these recommendations are being evaluated for implementation. The LADWP staff will document the completion of the recommended actions. 

Operating Procedures

      The LADWP has prepared written operating procedures for the LAAFP chlorination stations that provide clear instructions or steps for safely conducting activities relating to chlorination processes. They are consistent with the chlorine safety information. Written operating procedures included in the facility's Operation and Maintenance (O&M) Manuals are as follows:

* Delivery of Chlorine.
* Railcar Connect

power to all instrumentation and alarm systems while a backup generator will automatically start and take overpowering the entire facility. Chlorine flow will continue unaffected, with no safety consequences. Access to the plant is through security gates, which are kept locked or staffed by security officers all the time.

Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps 

      The LADWP accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:

* Detailed management system and clear levels of responsibilities and team member roles.
* Comprehensive process safety information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors.
* Comprehensive preventive maintenance program.
* Performance of process hazard analysis review of equipment and procedures with operation and maintenance staff participation and review.
* State-of-the-art process and safety equipment.
* Accurate and effective operating procedures, written with the participation of the station operators.
* High level training for the operators and maintenance staff.
* A State of California Water Treatment Facility Staff Certification is required to operate the station.
* An incident investigation, inspection, and auditing program using qualified staff.

      Chemical-specific prevention steps include the following: availability of self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), worn by the operators during connection/disconnection of chlorine supply; awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine; presence of chlorine detectors and alarms with remote monitoring, use of Midland and automatic shutoff valve actuators; operation of four dry media chlorine main scrubbers; and four dry media chlorine mini-scrubbers.

Process and Chemical Safety Information

      Comprehensive chemical data has been assembled to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazard, and chemical exposure limitations, as well a

ine and pumped to a higher pressure to supply the injectors. 

      Chlorine leak detectors are provided to detect chlorine leaks in the chlorine storage room which alarm locally as well as at the LAAFP control room in Sylmar. Leak detectors are also provided in the diffuser vaults with local flashing red lights as well as remote alarms at LAAFP. 

      The station is equipped with a dry media chlorine scrubber system with a capacity of 4700 lbs. of chlorine (equivalent capacity of two overfilled ton containers). The scrubber is actuated by chlorine detectors at a concentration of 3 ppm. Chlorine leak detectors are provided in the scrubber intake and discharge ducting to monitor scrubber performance if necessary. The outlet detector also generates an alarm at the LAAFP Control Room at a chlorine concentration of 1 ppm. The scrubber control panel has a Not In Auto warning light and remote alarm to remind Operators to make sure it is set in automatic mode.

      The automatic shutoff valve actuators on the ton containers are activated by a reading of 10 ppm chlorine at any two of the detectors in the chlorine storage or chlorinator rooms. These actuators can also be actuated by pressing one of the red mushroom switches located on any of the automatic shutoff valve actuator panels, or by the exit doors from the chlorine storage room.  

      A dry media chlorine mini-scrubber unit (MS) has also been installed at the VNCS#2. The mini-scrubber exhausts to the main scrubber intake. The MS is an emergency chlorine scrubber intended to protect personnel working in the building or immediate area from a chlorine gas release in the event of the failure of a vacuum regulating valve or a diaphragm leak in a pressure regulating valve. The mini-scrubber is activated automatically at a chlorine concentration of 1 ppm by the chlorine detector installed inside the plenum of the mini-scrubber. 

      In the event power is lost at the VNCS#2, UPS power will maintain continuous

er will maintain continuous power to all instrumentation and alarm systems while a backup generator will automatically start and take overpowering the entire facility. Chlorine flow will continue unaffected, with no safety consequences. Access to the plant is through security gates, which are kept locked or staffed by security officers all the time.

      The Van Norman Chloramination Station #2 - The chlorine storage system consists of two banks of two ton containers plus four spare ton containers. Each of the two banks of ton containers can be manifolded to a gas or liquid chlorine headers. All the four ton containers in these feed banks are equipped with automatic shutoff valve actuators that automatically close the ton container angle valve(s) when desired. The spare ton containers are not equipped with these actuators, as they are not connected to the process.

      Liquid chlorine is normally withdrawn from a bank of up to two manifolded chlorine ton containers to supply pressurized chlorine to the evaporator feed header. A second backup bank of up to two manifolded chlorine ton containers is connected to a gas backup header system. This gas backup system ensures continuous feed of chlorine to the process. It is equipped with automatic switchover type vacuum regulating valves that prevent the flow of chlorine gas until the vacuum in the header downstream starts to increase, this is indicative of reduction in the chlorine gas supply. This will happen when the primary chlorine containers are empty or if a power failure or malfunction in the evaporator vacuum regulating valve system caused these valves to close, thereby eliminating any further chlorine feed. The station is equipped with backup power and multiple evaporators to minimize the chance that a power failure will cause a switch over to the gas backup.

      This station utilizes booster water pumps to provide the necessary water pressure to operate the injectors. Suction water is taken from the 120 l

e chance that a power failure will cause a switch over to the gas backup.

      Chlorine leak detectors are provided to detect chlorine leaks in the chlorine storage room and the chlorinator room which alarm locally as well as at the LAAFP control room in Sylmar. Leak detectors are also provided in the diffuser vaults with local flashing red lights as well as remote alarms at LAAFP. 

      The station is equipped with a dry media chlorine scrubber system with a capacity of 4700 lbs. of chlorine (equivalent capacity of two overfilled ton containers). The scrubber is actuated by chlorine detectors at a concentration of 3 ppm. Chlorine leak detectors are provided in the scrubber intake and discharge ducting to monitor scrubber performance if necessary. The outlet sensor also generates an alarm at the LAAFP Control Room at a chlorine concentration of 1 ppm. The scrubber control panel has a Not In Auto warning light and remote alarm to remind Operators to make sure it is set in automatic mode.

      The automatic shutoff valve actuators on the ton containers are activated by a reading of 10 ppm chlorine at any two of the detectors in the chlorine storage or chlorinator rooms. These actuators can also be actuated by pressing one of the red mushroom switches located on any of the automatic valve actuator panels, or by the exit doors from the chlorine storage room.  

      A dry media chlorine mini-scrubber unit (MS) has also been installed at the VNCS#1. The mini-scrubber exhausts to the main scrubber intake. The MS is an emergency chlorine scrubber intended to protect personnel working in the building or immediate area from a chlorine gas release in the event of the failure of a vacuum regulating valve or a diaphragm leak in a pressure regulating valve. The mini-scrubber is activated automatically at a chlorine concentration of 1 ppm by the chlorine detector installed inside the plenum of the mini-scrubber. 

      In the event power is lost at the VNCS#1, UPS pow

g the probability of accidents involving chlorine ton containers. Additionally, all ton containers in the Depot are stored with their protective domes on to protect valves from accidental damage.

      In the event power is lost at the VNCD, an alarm will alert the control room.  Loss of power will cause the backup generator to take overpowering the entire station.  The chlorine scrubber will still be fully functional if needed, with no safety consequences. Access to the plant is through security gates, which are kept locked or staffed by security officers all the time.

      The Van Norman Chloramination Station #1 - The chlorine storage system consists of two banks of five ton containers plus five spare ton containers. Each of the two banks of ton containers can be manifolded to a gas or liquid chlorine headers. All the 10 ton containers in these feed banks are equipped with automatic shutoff valve actuators that automatically close the ton container angle valve(s) when desired. The spare ton containers are not equipped with these actuators, as they are not connected to the process.

      Liquid chlorine is normally withdrawn from a bank of up to five manifolded chlorine ton containers to supply pressurized chlorine to the evaporator feed header. A second backup bank of up to five manifolded chlorine ton containers is connected to a gas backup header system. This gas backup system ensures continuous feed of chlorine to the process. It is equipped with automatic switchover type vacuum regulating valves that prevent the flow of chlorine gas until the vacuum in the header downstream starts to increase, this is indicative of reduction in the chlorine gas supply. This will happen when the primary chlorine containers are empty or if a power failure or malfunction in the evaporator vacuum regulating valve system caused these valves to close, thereby eliminating any further chlorine feed. The station is equipped with backup power and multiple evaporators to minimize th

ation station at a concentration of 3 ppm. 

      A dry media chlorine mini-scrubber unit (MS) has also been installed in the chlorination room. The MS is an emergency chlorine scrubber intended to protect personnel working in the building or immediate area from a chlorine gas release in the event of the failure of a vacuum regulating valve or a diaphragm leak in a pressure regulating valve. The mini-scrubber is activated automatically at a chlorine concentration of 3 ppm. 

      Chlorine leak detectors are provided to detect chlorine leaks in the chlorinator and chlorine storage rooms, as well as in the vaults. The detector signals an alarm by activating (1) a flashing red light over the entry door to the building, (2) an audible alarm within the chlorination building, and (3) an alarm at the Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant Control Room.

      In the event power is lost at the Los Angeles Reservoir Outlet facility, an alarm will alert the control room. Loss of power will cause the backup generator to take over powering the entire station. Chlorine flow will continue unaffected with no safety consequences. Access to the plant is through security gates, which are kept, locked or staffed by security officers all the time.

      The Van Norman Chemical Depot - The Van Norman Chemical Depot is a structure used for the storage of various chemicals used by the LADWP. The Depot includes a large chlorine ton container storage room for receipt, storage and distribution of unopened chlorine ton containers. There are no chlorination processes at the facility.

      The Depot is equipped with chlorine leak detectors, which alarm locally as well as at the LAAFP's Control Room. The Depot is also equipped with a one-ton capacity dry media chlorine main scrubber, which is activated automatically in the event of a chlorine leak inside the Depot at a concentration of 3 ppm. Ton containers are moved about inside the building using a bridge crane system; therefore, reducin

ton containers can be connected to liquid or gas feed headers in the event the bulk tank is taken out of service for maintenance. Midland valve actuators are connected to both the liquid and gas valves on the bulk tank. The Midland valve actuators will close on the bulk tank when two of the chlorine detectors detect 10 ppm of chlorine in the chlorine storage room. Ton containers connected to the feed header are equipped with automatic shut off valve actuators that automatically close the ton container feed valve when a chlorine concentration of 10 ppm is detected in the chlorine storage room by two chlorine detectors. 

      Liquid chlorine is normally withdrawn from the bulk tank to a piping header that leads to either one of the three evaporators. The gas discharge piping from the evaporators supply pressurized chlorine gas to the chlorinators through pressure regulating valves. A gas header from the bulk tank serves as a backup supply that automatically takes over when the evaporator is shut off due to a low temperature condition. The bank of eight ton containers can also feed liquid or gaseous chlorine through the header system to the evaporators or chlorinators.

      There are a number of chlorine injectors located in four injection vaults. The injectors provide vacuum that draws chlorine gas from the chlorinators into mixing water to form a concentrated solution. The solution is piped through diffusers into the various water pipelines.  

      Control of the chlorination process is by proportional flow and residual chlorine feed pacing. Chlorine residual analyzers continuously monitor and record the treated water residuals.

      A dry media type chlorine gas scrubber system (main scrubber) is installed outside the chlorine storage room. The scrubber is designed to essentially neutralize any chlorine release from the PSV installed on the chlorine bulk storage tank. The scrubber is activated automatically by chlorine detectors installed inside the chlorin

ectly to the chlorinators. The evaporators vaporize the liquid in a water bath to form a superheated gas which passes through a pressure reducing valve and an evaporator activated vacuum regulating valve with check-relief unit, and then to the chlorinators. Chlorine gas from the vacuum regulating valve is pulled by vacuum to the chlorinators. The chlorinators regulate the gas flow and discharge it to the injection lines at the appropriate rate. Chlorine gas from the chlorinators is pulled by vacuum to injectors located on the downstream piping at various chlorine application points. 

      Multiple chlorine detectors continuously monitor the tank car area, ton container storage area, chlorine pipe trench and in the chlorination room. They alarm locally as well as at the operator's console in the control room.

      A dry media chlorine mini-scrubber unit (MS) has been installed in the LAAFP chlorination room. MS is an emergency chlorine scrubber intended to protect personnel working in the building or immediate area from a chlorine gas release in the event of the failure of a vacuum regulating valve or a diaphragm leak in a pressure regulating valve. It can neutralize up to 25 lbs. of chlorine. The mini-scrubber is activated automatically at a chlorine concentration of 3 ppm.

      In the event power is lost at the LAAFP facility, two backup generators will automatically start and take overpowering the entire facility. Chlorine flow will continue unaffected, with no safety consequences.

      The LAAFP control room at the plant is staffed 24 hours a day, year-round.  Access to the plant is through security gates, which are kept locked or staffed by security officers all the time.

      The Los Angeles Reservoir Outlet Chlorination Station - The primary supply of liquid chlorine at the LAROCS is from a 25-ton capacity bulk tank. A gas line is also connected to the bulk tank to serve as a backup supply if the liquid supply is disabled. Additionally, up to eight

a tank car valves shutdown (Midland and Jamesbury valves will shut down). Each detector must exceed 10 ppm to trigger a shut down. This detector combination minimizes the possibility of shutting down a tank car on just one detector false alarm or faulty detector. The Midland valve actuators can also be manually triggered from the following three locations: (1) Tank Car Platform Chlorine Control Panel (2) Chlorinator Room Chlorine Control Panel, and (3) Control Room SCADA system. In addition to the Midland actuators, there are three Jamesbury actuators on the hard piping to the flex hoses. The Midland actuators are for the tank car (the source) and the Jamesbury actuators are for the process feed piping. The Jamesbury valves are connected to the hard piping which is connected to the flex hoses; this closure is for stopping the possible backflow of chlorine in case a crack is developed in the flex hose. The chlorine leak detector can serve as a monitoring/alarm and/or perform shutdown function. The chlorine detectors near or on the tank car serve as a monitoring/alarm as well as perform the shutdown function.

      In addition, to the leak detectors and capability to shut down tank cars, each tank car is set up with a pair of motion sensors. The motion sensors are at the top chain of the interlock system for the tank car.

      The ton containers connected to the feed header are also equipped with automatic shutoff valve actuators. These valve actuators are installed on the angle valves of the ton containers that automatically close the ton container feed valve when a chlorine concentration of 10 ppm is detected in the ton container storage area. The automatic shutoff valve actuator is an automatic-closing, fail-safe valve closer that supplements the manual operation of the ton container valve by providing for powered valve closure in case of an emergency.

      Liquid chlorine travels under pressure to evaporator units, while gaseous chlorine can be withdrawn dir

ntainer feed valve when a chlorine concentration of 10 ppm is detected in the room. The spare ton containers are not equipped with these actuators, as these containers cannot be connected to the process in the storage location. The station is equipped with a dry media chlorine scrubber system with a capacity of 4,700 lbs. of chlorine. The scrubber is actuated by chlorine detectors at a concentration of 3 ppm. 

      The Van Norman Chloramination Station #2 is also used to establish a chloramine residual in the treated water. The chlorine storage system consists of two banks of ton containers plus additional spare ton containers. The ton container is the largest vessel (container) on-site. Each of the ton containers in the two feed banks are equipped with automatic shutoff valve actuators that automatically close the ton container feed valve when a chlorine concentration of 10 ppm is detected in the room. The spare ton containers are not equipped with these actuators, as these containers cannot be connected to the process in the storage location. The station is equipped with a dry media chlorine scrubber system with a capacity of 4,700 lbs. of chlorine. The scrubber is actuated by chlorine detectors at a concentration of 3 ppm. 

      Additional details of the above five facilities are provided below.

      The Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant - Liquid chlorine is supplied to the Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant in 90-ton tank cars with a backup of ton containers for the chlorination process. Liquid or gaseous chlorine can be withdrawn from the tank cars. Midland valve actuators are connected to the liquid and/or gas connections on the tank cars. The Midland valve actuators will close on the tank car Midland valves and stop the flow of chlorine when 10 ppm of chlorine is detected in the area. A combination of two chlorine leak detectors, located near the hatch of the tank car, the platform of the tank car, or near the bottom of the tank car, will trigger

on railcar is the largest vessel (container) online.

      The Los Angeles Reservoir Outlet Chlorination Station serves to chlorinate water in a single 120 diameter pipeline exiting the reservoir. The primary injection point is downstream of the Los Angeles Reservoir Ultraviolet Disinfection Plant (LARUVDP). The backup injection is upstream of the LARUVDP. The treated water is then piped into the distribution network which serves much of the San Fernando Valley with potable water and feeds other reservoirs. It also chlorinates the outlet flow from the Van Norman Bypass Reservoir and another pipeline called the Rinaldi Trunk Line. This station stores chlorine in a 25-ton bulk storage tank; it can also store eight chlorine ton containers to be used when the bulk tank is taken out of service for maintenance or repair. The 25-ton bulk tank is the largest vessel (container) online. The station is equipped with a dry media chlorine main scrubber of one-ton capacity. This scrubber will neutralize any chlorine release from the pressure safety valve (PSV) installed on the chlorine bulk storage tank as well as from a ton container. The chlorine scrubber is activated by chlorine detectors at a concentration of 3 ppm.

      The Van Norman Chemical Depot is used for storage of unopened chlorine ton containers in addition to various other chemicals. The ton container is the largest vessel (container) on-site. The depot is equipped with a one-ton capacity dry media chlorine scrubber. The chlorine scrubber is activated by chlorine detectors at a concentration of 3 ppm. 

      The Van Norman Chloramination Station #1 is used to establish a chloramine residual in the treated water. The chlorine storage system consists of two banks of ton containers plus additional spare ton containers. The ton container is the largest vessel (container) on-site. Each of the ton containers in the two feed banks are equipped with automatic shutoff valve actuators that automatically close the ton co

Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.
* General facility and regulated substances information.
* Summary of the accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps.
* Five-year accident history summary.
* Emergency response program summary.
* Planned changes to improve safety.

      The above information for the LAAFP chlorine storage and handling facilities is provided below.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

      The LADWP accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates the use of proven technology, trains staff in operation and maintenance practices, and uses tested and proven management system practices. All applicable requirements of the State of California and the EPA's Prevention Program are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response procedures.  

      The LADWP emergency response policy involves the preparation of emergency response plans for hazardous materials, which are tailored to each facility and to the emergency response services available in the community, and is in compliance with the EPA Emergency Response Program Requirements. The LADWP has prepared an Emergency Response Plan to facilitate coordination and emergency planning with offsite response officials and facilities in the event of an emergency. The Emergency Response Plan has been coordinated with the local response agency (City of Los Angeles Fire Department). 

General Facility and Regulated Substance Information

      The five LAAFP chlorine processes are located in the same complex adjacent to the Los Angeles Reservoir in Sylmar, California.

      The Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant treats up to 600 million gallons per day of water from the Los Angeles Owens River Aqueduct or from the Metropolitan Water District. Liquid chlorine is delivered to the plant in 90-ton railcars or by truck in ton containers. The 90-t

Chlorine is the most commonly used substance for disinfecting drinking water. The addition of chlorine or chlorine compounds to water is called chlorination. Chlorination is considered to be the most important process for preventing the spread of waterborne disease in drinking water. The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power (LADWP) also uses chlorine for drinking water disinfection purposes at the Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) facilities to protect public health per state and federal water quality standards.

       The LAAFP facilities complex consists of four different chlorination stations and one chemical depot: (1) the LAAFP facility; (2) the Los Angeles Reservoir Outlet Chlorination Station (LAROCS); (3) the Van Norman Chemical Depot (VNCD); (4) the Van Norman Chloramination Station # 1 (VNCS#1); and (5) the Van Norman Chloramination Station #2 (VNCS#2).

      The LAAFP facilities chlorine handling processes are subject to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program and Plan and to the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program and Plan requirements. These five facilities are also subject to the California Occupational Safety and Health Administration (Cal/OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard. The facilities subject to the EPA and the CalARP regulations are required to prepare and update Risk Management Plans (RMPs). An update of the RMP is required at least once every five years from the date of its initial submission. The RMP is to include policies and procedures followed to safely operate the facility and the actions, which will be taken by the facility in an event of an emergency.

      The LADWP prepared Program 3 Risk Management Plan for the LAAFP facilities in June 2019. This 2024 update of the 2019 RMP for the LAAFP facilities also demonstrates compliance with Program 3 requirements.
